metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript ES5
ECMAScript 2009, also known as ES5, was the first major revision to JavaScript.
content.html: ECMAScript 2009, also known as ES5, was the first major revision to JavaScript.

content.text: This chapter describes the most important features of ES5.
content.html: This chapter describes the most important features of ES5.

content.text: ES5 Features
Browser Support
ES5 (JavaScript 2009) fully supported in all modern browsers since July 2013:
content.html: ES5 (JavaScript 2009) fully supported in all modern browsers since July 2013:

content.code_html:
Chrome
23		 IE/Edge
10		 Firefox
21		 Safari
6		 Opera
15
Sep 2012 Sep 2012 Apr 2013 Jul 2012 Jul 2013

content.text: The "use strict" Directive
"use strict" defines that the JavaScript code should be executed in "strict mode".
content.html: "use strict" defines that the JavaScript code should be executed in "strict mode".

content.text: With strict mode you can, for example, not use undeclared variables.
content.html: With strict mode you can, for example, not use undeclared variables.

content.text: You can use strict mode in all your programs. It helps you to write cleaner code, like preventing you from using undeclared variables.
content.html: You can use strict mode in all your programs. It helps you to write cleaner code, like preventing you from using undeclared variables.

content.text: "use strict" is just a string expression. Old browsers will not throw an error if they don't understand it.
content.html: "use strict" is just a string expression. Old browsers will not throw an error if they don't understand it.

content.text: Read more in JS Strict Mode .
content.html: Read more in JS Strict Mode.

content.text: Property Access on Strings
The charAt() method returns the character at a specified index (position) in a string:
content.html: The charAt() method returns the character at a specified index (position) in a string:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str.charAt(0);            // returns H

content.code:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str.charAt(0);            // returns H

syntax_highlighting.text:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str.charAt(0);            // returns H

content.code_html:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str.charAt(0);            // returns H

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str.charAt(0);            // returns H

content.text: ES5 allows property access on strings:
content.html: ES5 allows property access on strings:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str[0];                   // returns H

content.code:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str[0];                   // returns H

syntax_highlighting.text:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str[0];                   // returns H

content.code_html:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str[0];                   // returns H

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var str = "HELLO WORLD";
str[0];                   // returns H

content.text: Property access on string might be a little unpredictable.
content.html: Property access on string might be a little unpredictable.

content.text: Read more in JS String Methods .
content.html: Read more in JS String Methods.

content.text: Strings Over Multiple Lines

content.code: "Hello \Dolly!";
content.code_html:
"Hello \
Dolly!";

content.text: The \ method might not have universal support. Older browsers might treat the spaces around the backslash differently. Some older browsers do not allow spaces behind the \ character.
content.html:
The \ method might not have universal support.
Older browsers might treat the spaces around the backslash differently.
Some older browsers do not allow spaces behind the \ character.

content.text: A safer way to break up a string literal, is to use string addition:
content.html: A safer way to break up a string literal, is to use string addition:

content.code: "Hello " + "Dolly!";
content.code_html:
"Hello " +
"Dolly!";

content.text: Reserved Words as Property Names
ES5 allows reserved words as property names:
content.html: ES5 allows reserved words as property names:

content.code: var obj = {name: "John", new: "yes"}
content.code_html: var obj = {name: "John", new: "yes"}

content.text: String trim()
The trim() method removes whitespace from both sides of a string.
content.html: The trim() method removes whitespace from both sides of a string.

content.code: var str = "       Hello World!        ";alert(str.trim());
content.code_html:
var str = "       Hello World!        ";
alert(str.trim());

content.text: Read more in JS String Methods .
content.html: Read more in JS String Methods.

content.text: Array.isArray()
The isArray() method checks whether an object is an array.
content.html: The isArray() method checks whether an object is an array.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction() {  var fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];  var x = document.getElementById("demo");
    x.innerHTML = Array.isArray(fruits);}

content.code:
function myFunction() {  var fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];  var x = document.getElementById("demo");
x.innerHTML = Array.isArray(fruits);}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction() {  var fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];  var x = document.getElementById("demo");
    x.innerHTML = Array.isArray(fruits);}

content.code_html:
function myFunction() {
  var fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
  var x = document.getElementById("demo");
  x.innerHTML = Array.isArray(fruits);
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction() {  var fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];  var x = document.getElementById("demo");
    x.innerHTML = Array.isArray(fruits);}

content.text: Read more in JS Arrays .
content.html: Read more in JS Arrays.

content.text: Array forEach()
The forEach() method calls a function once for each array element.
content.html: The forEach() method calls a function once for each array element.

content.code_html:
var txt = "";
var numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
numbers.forEach(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {
  txt = txt + value + "<br>";
}

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .
content.html: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.

content.text: Array map()
This example multiplies each array value by 2:
content.html: This example multiplies each array value by 2:

content.code_html:
var numbers1 = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
var numbers2 = numbers1.map(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {
  return value * 2;
}

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .
content.html: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.

content.text: Array filter()
This example creates a new array from elements with a value larger than 18:
content.html: This example creates a new array from elements with a value larger than 18:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];var over18 = 
  numbers.filter(myFunction);function myFunction(value) {  return value > 18;}

numbers.filter(myFunction);function myFunction(value) {  return value > 18;}

var over18 = numbers.filter(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {

}

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .
content.html: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.

content.text: Array reduce()
This example finds the sum of all numbers in an array:
content.html: This example finds the sum of all numbers in an array:

content.code_html:
var numbers1 = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
var sum = numbers1.reduce(myFunction);

function myFunction(total, value) {
  return total + value;
}

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .
content.html: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.

This example also finds the sum of all numbers in an array:
content.html: This example also finds the sum of all numbers in an array:

  function myFunction(total, value) {  return total + value;}

function myFunction(total, value) {  return total + value;}

 function myFunction(total, value) {  return total + value;}

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .

content.text: Array every()
This example checks if all values are over 18:
content.html: This example checks if all values are over 18:

content.code_html:
var numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
var allOver18 = numbers.every(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .
content.html: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.

content.text: Array some()
This example checks if some values are over 18:
content.html: This example checks if some values are over 18:

content.code_html:
var numbers = [45, 4, 9, 16, 25];
var allOver18 = numbers.some(myFunction);

function myFunction(value) {
  return value > 18;
}

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .
content.html: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.

content.text: Array indexOf()
Search an array for an element value and returns its position.
content.html: Search an array for an element value and returns its position.

content.code:
var fruits = ["Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
var a = fruits.indexOf("Apple");
content.code_html:
var fruits = ["Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
var a = fruits.indexOf("Apple");

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .
content.html: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.

content.text: Array lastIndexOf()
lastIndexOf() is the same as indexOf() , but searches from the end of the array.
content.html: lastIndexOf() is the same as indexOf(), but searches from the end of the array.

content.code:
var fruits = ["Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
var a = fruits.lastIndexOf("Apple");
content.code_html:
var fruits = ["Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
var a = fruits.lastIndexOf("Apple");

content.text: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods .
content.html: Learn more in JS Array Iteration Methods.

content.text: JSON.parse()
A common use of JSON is to receive data from a web server.
content.html: A common use of JSON is to receive data from a web server.

content.text: Imagine you received this text string from a web server:
content.html: Imagine you received this text string from a web server:

content.code: '{"name":"John", "age":30, "city":"New York"}'
content.code_html: '{"name":"John", "age":30, "city":"New York"}'

content.text: The JavaScript function JSON.parse() is used to convert the text into a JavaScript object:
content.html: The JavaScript function JSON.parse() is used to convert the text into a JavaScript object:

content.code:
var obj = JSON.parse('{"name":"John", "age":30, "city":"New
York"}');
content.code_html: var obj = JSON.parse('{"name":"John", "age":30, "city":"New York"}');

content.text: Read more in our JSON Tutorial .
content.html: Read more in our JSON Tutorial.

content.text: JSON.stringify()
A common use of JSON is to send data to a web server.
content.html: A common use of JSON is to send data to a web server.

content.text: When sending data to a web server, the data has to be a string.
content.html: When sending data to a web server, the data has to be a string.

content.text: Imagine we have this object in JavaScript:
content.html: Imagine we have this object in JavaScript:

content.code: var obj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};
content.code_html: var obj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};

content.text: Use the JavaScript function JSON.stringify() to convert it into a string.
content.html: Use the JavaScript function JSON.stringify() to convert it into a string.

content.code: var myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);
content.code_html: var myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.text: The result will be a string following the JSON notation.
content.html: The result will be a string following the JSON notation.

content.text: myJSON is now a string, and ready to be sent to a server:
content.html: myJSON is now a string, and ready to be sent to a server:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var obj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};
var myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = myJSON;

content.code:
var obj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};
var myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = myJSON;

syntax_highlighting.text:
var obj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};
var myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = myJSON;

content.code_html:
var obj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};
var myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = myJSON;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var obj = {name:"John", age:30, city:"New York"};
var myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = myJSON;

content.text: Read more in our JSON Tutorial .
content.html: Read more in our JSON Tutorial.

content.text: Date.now()
Date.now() returns the number of milliseconds since zero date (January 1. 1970 00:00:00 UTC).
content.html: Date.now() returns the number of milliseconds since zero date (January 1. 1970 00:00:00 UTC).

content.code: var timInMSs = Date.now();
content.code_html: var timInMSs = Date.now();

content.text: Date.now() returns the same as getTime() performed on a Date object.
content.html: Date.now() returns the same as getTime() performed on a Date object.

content.text: Learn more in JS Dates .
content.html: Learn more in JS Dates.

content.text: Date toISOString()
The toISOString() method converts a Date object to a string, using the ISO standard format:
content.html: The toISOString() method converts a Date object to a string, using the ISO standard format:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toISOString();

content.code:
const d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toISOString();

syntax_highlighting.text:
const d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toISOString();

content.code_html:
const d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toISOString();

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toISOString();

content.text: Date toJSON()
toJSON() converts a Date object into a string, formatted as a JSON date.
content.html: toJSON() converts a Date object into a string, formatted as a JSON date.

content.text: JSON dates have the same format as the ISO-8601 standard: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ:
content.html: JSON dates have the same format as the ISO-8601 standard: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ:

content.code:
d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toJSON();
content.code_html:
d = new Date();
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = d.toJSON();

content.text: Property Getters and Setters
ES5 lets you define object methods with a syntax that looks like getting or setting a property.
content.html: ES5 lets you define object methods with a syntax that looks like getting or setting a property.

content.text: This example creates a getter for a property called fullName:
content.html: This example creates a getter for a property called fullName:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Display data from the 
  object using a getter:

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Display data from the 
  object using a getter:

content.code_html:
// Create an object:
var person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  get fullName() {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
};

// Display data from the object using a getter:
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.fullName;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Display data from the 
  object using a getter:

content.text: This example creates a setter and a getter for the language property:
content.html: This example creates a setter and a getter for the language property:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Set an object 
  property using a setter:

// Display data from the 
  object using a getter:

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Set an object 
  property using a setter:

// Display data from the 
  object using a getter:

content.code_html:
var person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  language : "NO",
  get lang() {
    return this.language;
  },
  set lang(value) {
    this.language = value;
  }
};

// Set an object property using a setter:
person.lang = "en";

// Display data from the object using a getter:
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.lang;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Set an object 
  property using a setter:

// Display data from the 
  object using a getter:

content.text: This example uses a setter to secure upper case updates of language:
content.html: This example uses a setter to secure upper case updates of language:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Set an object 
  property using a setter:

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Set an object 
  property using a setter:

content.code_html:
var person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  language : "NO",
  set lang(value) {
    this.language = value.toUpperCase();
  }
};

// Set an object property using a setter:
person.lang = "en";

// Display data from the object:
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.language;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Set an object 
  property using a setter:

content.text: Learn more about Gettes and Setters in JS Object Accessors
content.html: Learn more about Gettes and Setters in JS Object Accessors

content.text: Object.defineProperty()
Object.defineProperty() is a new Object method in ES5.
content.html: Object.defineProperty() is a new Object method in ES5.

content.text: It lets you define an object property and/or change a property's value and/or metadata.
content.html: It lets you define an object property and/or change a property's value and/or metadata.

content.code_html:
// Create an Object:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  language : "NO",
};

// Change a Property:
Object.defineProperty(person, "language", {
  value: "EN",
  writable : true,
  enumerable : true,
  configurable : true
});

// Enumerate Properties
let txt = "";
for (let x in person) {
  txt += person[x] + "<br>";
}

// Display Properties
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = txt;

content.text: Next example is the same code, except it hides the language property from enumeration:
content.html: Next example is the same code, except it hides the language property from enumeration:

content.code_html:
// Create an Object:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  language : "NO",
};

// Change a Property:
Object.defineProperty(person, "language", {
  value: "EN",
  writable : true,
  enumerable : false,
  configurable : true
});

// Enumerate Properties
let txt = "";
for (let x in person) {
  txt += person[x] + "<br>";
}
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = txt;

content.text: This example creates a setter and a getter to secure upper case updates of language:
content.html: This example creates a setter and a getter to secure upper case updates of language:

content.code_html:
// Create an Object:
const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName : "Doe",
  language : "NO"
};

// Change a Property:
 Object.defineProperty(person, "language", {
  get : function() { return language },
  set : function(value) { language = value.toUpperCase()}
});

// Change Language
person.language = "en";

// Display Language
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = person.language;

content.text: Object.create()
The Object.create() method creates an object from an existing object.
content.html: The Object.create() method creates an object from an existing object.

content.code_html:
// Create an Object:
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe"
};

// Create new Object
 const man = Object.create(person);
man.firstName = "Peter";

content.text: Object.keys()
The Object.keys() method returns an array with the keys of an object.
content.html: The Object.keys() method returns an array with the keys of an object.

content.code_html:
// Create an Object
 const person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  age: 50,
  eyeColor: "blue"
};

// Get the Keys
 const keys = Object.keys(person);

content.text: Object Management
ES5 added new Object management methods to JavaScript:
content.html: ES5 added new Object management methods to JavaScript:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Adding or changing an object property
// Returns all properties as an array

syntax_highlighting.text: // Adding or changing an object property
// Returns all properties as an array

content.code_html:
// Adding or changing an object property
 Object.defineProperty(object, property, descriptor)

// Adding or changing object properties
 Object.defineProperties(object, descriptors)

// Accessing a Property
 Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor(object, property)

// Accessing Properties
 Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors(object)

// Returns all properties as an array
 Object.getOwnPropertyNames(object)

// Accessing the prototype
 Object.getPrototypeOf(object)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Adding or changing an object property
// Returns all properties as an array

content.text: Object Protection
ES5 added Object protection methods to JavaScript:
content.html: ES5 added Object protection methods to JavaScript:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Prevents adding properties to an object
// Returns true if properties can be added to an object
// Prevents changes of object properties (not values)
// Returns true if object is sealed
// Prevents any changes to an object
// Returns true if object is frozen

syntax_highlighting.text: // Prevents adding properties to an object
// Returns true if properties can be added to an object
// Prevents changes of object properties (not values)
// Returns true if object is sealed
// Prevents any changes to an object
// Returns true if object is frozen

content.code_html:
// Prevents adding properties to an object
 Object.preventExtensions(object)

// Returns true if properties can be added to an object
 Object.isExtensible(object)

// Prevents changes of object properties (not values)
 Object.seal(object)

// Returns true if object is sealed
 Object.isSealed(object)

// Prevents any changes to an object
 Object.freeze(object)

// Returns true if object is frozen
 Object.isFrozen(object)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Prevents adding properties to an object
// Returns true if properties can be added to an object
// Prevents changes of object properties (not values)
// Returns true if object is sealed
// Prevents any changes to an object
// Returns true if object is frozen

content.text: Function Bind()
With the bind() method, an object can borrow a method from another object.
content.html: With the bind() method, an object can borrow a method from another object.

content.text: This example creates 2 objects (person and member).
content.html: This example creates 2 objects (person and member).

content.text: The member object borrows the fullname method from the person object:
content.html: The member object borrows the fullname method from the person object:

content.code_html:
const person = {
  firstName:"John",
  lastName: "Doe",
  fullName: function () {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  }
}

const member = {
  firstName:"Hege",
  lastName: "Nilsen",
}

let fullName = person.fullName.bind(member);

content.text: Learn more in Function bind() .
content.html: Learn more in Function bind().

content.text: Trailing Commas
ES5 allows trailing commas in object and array definitions:
content.html: ES5 allows trailing commas in object and array definitions:

content.code_html:
person = {
  firstName: "John",
  lastName: " Doe",
  age: 46,
}

points = [
  1,
  5,
  10,
  25,
  40,
  100,
];

content.text: WARNING !!!
content.html: WARNING !!!

content.text: JSON does not allow trailing commas.
content.html: JSON does not allow trailing commas.

content.code:
//
Allowed:var person = '{"firstName":"John", "lastName":"Doe",
"age":46}'JSON.parse(person)// Not allowed:var person = '{"firstName":"John",
"lastName":"Doe", "age":46,}'JSON.parse(person)
content.code_html:
// Allowed:
var person = '{"firstName":"John", "lastName":"Doe", "age":46}'
JSON.parse(person)

// Not allowed:
var person = '{"firstName":"John", "lastName":"Doe", "age":46,}'
JSON.parse(person)
